location: MAX'S APARTMENT -CHINATOWN FLAT NEW YORK CITY

text: Max jolts his head from his desk and tries to orient him- in the darkness. He has intelligent eyes set in an exhaus good-looking face. Then he notices the blood dripping from his nose. Max wip it. Max's voiceover begins:
Monday, September first.  Six-fifteen.
A pull-string light flips on. Max examines his bloody nos the mirror.
The alchemist awakes.  (Imitating)
"Turn lead into gold, Max,  lead into gold." Today, I find it.

Max's hand as three unmarked, circular pills hit his palm Then, he slams the pills into the back of his mouth. Max replaces the cap on a plastic bottle of unmarked  prescription drugs. He drinks from the sink and splashes generous amount of water onto his head and face, cleaning nose. He wipes his nose and examines the last remnants of blood his fingertip. Then, he dips his finger under the tap.

Max's room is constantly dark because the windows are bla out. He flips on his desk lamp. A tiny ANT crawls across his desk. He looks at it for a m before getting angry and squashing it. Sitting on the desk are three computer monitors, which Ma flips on. Then he pops on more lights and more switches. We pull ba revealing that Max's apartment looks more like the inside computer than a human's home. The room is knee-high in computer parts of all shapes and sizes. The walls are covered with circuit boards. Cables from the ceiling like vines in a Brazilian rain forest. T all seem to be wired together forming a monstrous homemad computer. This is EUCLID, Max's creation. The computer is alive wit sounds and lights. Max works on Euclid with his solder and drill. He cares f the machine as if it were his dream car

Heat's been getting  to Euclid. Feel it most in  the afternoon when I run the  set. Have to keep the fans on  all night from now on.  Otherwise, everything is  running topnotch. The stack  of 286's is now faster than  Columbia's computer science  department. I spent a couple  hundred dollars. Columbia's  cost? Half a million?  (Small snicker)
Ha... Max checks the peephole on His front door. No one is ther unbolts the five lock and slides into the hall.
As he secures his apartment, a Young girl named JENNA run to him. Her MOM, down the hall, looks apologetic. Jenna's eyes light up and she pulls out her Fisher Price  calculator.
Max, Max! Can we do one?
(Over and over again)
Jenna! Jenna!
Oh, no.
What's three hundred  and twenty-two times four  hundred and ninety-one. Jenna types it into her calculator. Max finishes locking door.
(instantly)
One hundred fifty-eight thousand,  a hundred two. Right?
(Eyes light up)
Right. Max heads down the staircase.
Jenna... Jenna screams after him.
Okay, seventy-three  divided by twenty-two.
(instantly again)
Three point three one eight one  eight one eight...
Max watches people bustle through the busy intersections Chinatown. The streets are clogged with people.
Somewhere in there.  Somewhere. I know it's right  in front of me. The pattern.  They say it's chaos, it can't  be understood, too much  complexity.
Max scavenges electronic parts as he carefully navigates endless dump for old and rotting computers.
History it's there.  Lurking, shaping.  structuring, hiding, right  beneath the surface. He unscrews a random IBM Board from a keyboard and slides into his pocket.
on Max looking up at something as he reclines on a public bench.

The cycling of disease epidemics,  the wax and wane of Caribou populations  in the Arctic, sunspot cycles,  the rise and fall of the  Nile and yes! the New York Stock  Exchange, they are all the  same.
on a tree branch - shaking gently in the wind.
Bright stock quotes drift across the screen.
I'll find this structure,  this order, this perfection.
Max stares intensely at the ticker on the small TV that s next to his monitors.

Turn lead into gold.  The first. Right here. Right  here. With math. The numbers  of the stock market are my  lead. When I find the  pattern, then I will find  gold. Max watches the right edge of the screen where the number appear. He wants to see what's before that edge... Max slaps the RETURN button on his computer. The phone starts ringing. Max eyes it suspiciously. Just then, Euclid starts printing results on an old dot- matrix printer. Max suspiciously answers The phone.
Hello?
Maximilian Cohen, please.
Yeah?
Mr. Cohen?
Who's this?
Hi. my name is Marcy Dawson.  I'm a partner with the predictive  strategy firm Lancet-Percy. Can I  speak with Mr. Cohen, please?
I told you... The printer finishes printing.
Mr. Cohen! How  are you? It's been a long  time. Sorry I haven't been in  touch. But I was hoping you  would allow me to take you to  lunch tomorrow, say one  o'clock?
Sorry, I can't.
We're very anxious to talk  with you, sir
I can't.
I'm prepared to  make you a generous... Max hurries to wrap up the conversation.
I don't take offers for  my research. You know that.  Sorry, I Couldn't help you.

Mr. Cohen, give  me a moment... But before Marcy finishes, Max hangs up. He rips off the  printout and heads to the front door. He checks the peephole, His landlady. MRS. OVADIA, is swe the hallway stairs humming a turn-of-the century (the las one, not this one) tune. Max waits a moment. He tousles his hair. Then he checks a She's gone. He opens his locks and releases several bolts

Max locks his front door. Meanwhile, his next-door neighb DEVI MINSTRY, a sexy young Indian woman, is just getting Max looks away and tries to get his door locked. She's weighted down by a bunch of bags filled with food.
Max, good!
Hi, Devi.
I grabbed you some  somosas.
Great. Devi heads over to Max with her bags of food. She looks u Max.
Your hair. Devi hands the bags to Max. Then she goes to pat down his Hair. Max retreats.
What are you doing?
Your hair, you can't go  out like that. Don't worry.
It's fine. It's fine. Devi pats down his hair. Max is humiliated.
You need a mom. Max hands back the bags and heads quickly for the stairs.
I have to go.
Your somosas! An embarrassed Max takes the bag.
Thanks.
At the counter, Max stirs cream into his coffee. Then he three pills from the plastic bottle and drops them in his coffee. Max flips past a full-page ad in the paper that reads
Max flips the page before he or we can absorb it. He comp stock quotes in the Wall Street Journal against his print

Sixteen, twenty-seven. Results: Euclid  shows tomorrow's Dow closing  up by four points. Anomalies  include PRONET at sixty-fire  and a quarter, a career high.  Possible explanations, either  A, an error in the June fifth  algorithm, or B, Euclid's  main processor is running a  recursion... Max marks up the paper with lines and diagrams as he pond his bits and misses. Then a puff of cigarette smoke drifts by and succeeds in  bothering Max. He fans it away when

Oh sorry, am I bothering you? Max shrugs and looks over. The voice belongs to LENNY MEYERa bearded man in his late sucking on a cigarette. On closer inspection, something is off. It seems that Len an Orthodox Jew. His yarmulke sticks out Slightly from hi wide-brimmed hat and the fringes from his tsi-tsis hang o from the bottom of his untucked shirt.
I'll put it out.  (Which he does)
The name's Lenny Meyer Lenny sticks out his hand. Max responds with a small nod.
And you are?
Max.
Max?
Max Cohen.
Cohen!  (Judging)
Jewish?  Max shrugs and turns back to his work.
It's okay.  (Joking)  I'm a Jew, too.  (Serious)  Do you practice?
No, I'm not interested  in religion.
Have you ever  heard of Kabbalah?
No.
Jewish mysticism.
I'm sorry, I'm very busy.
I understand...it's just that  it's a very exciting time in  our history. Right now is a  critical moment in time.
(Sarcastic)
Really?
Yes, it's very exciting.  Have you ever put on Tefillin? Max has no idea what Lenny's talking about. Lenny pulls a leather box with black leather straps from his pocket.

Tefillin. You know Tefillin.  I know it looks strange.  But it's an amazing  tradition that has a  tremendous amount of power.  It's a mitzvah for all  Jewish men to do. Mitzvahs,  good deeds, are spiritual  food for our hearts and our  heads. And then Max notices that his thumb is twitching He grabs self-consciously.
They purify us and bring us  closer to God. You want to try it? Just then, Max pays his bill and prepares to leave.
I gotta go...
Are you okay? Max? Max?
I'm sorry, bye.
Well, maybe some other time.
Max splashes water on his face.

Please God, Let it be a  small one. He pulls a metal vaccinating gun out of the medicine cabi Then be loads it with a small bottle of medicine. He roll his sleeve, dabs alcohol on his arm, and fires the gun in his arm.

Sixteen thirty-five.  Second headache in under  twenty-four hours. They're  getting more frequent  now...more painful, too. Drugs  don't work, just take the  edge off of it. Just gotta  wait for the nosebleed.  Relief comes from my nose. Next door, he hears Devi and her boyfriend talking.
So I gotta make this drop off  in Harlem and on the way down  there's these three kids  hailing me. Max slaps himself in the face a few times.
You stopped?

I was tight, so... Max watches his thumb twitch. And then pain shoots throug him. He grabs the right side of his head, massages it, an pushes it in with his fingers. In the mirror, he examines the right side of his scalp. H sees nothing
Ahh... Max walks back into the
and sits down in a chair. The lamp is blinding so he snaps it off. Only the bathroom light lights the room. He takes a few breaths.
Leave me alone. His neighbors conversation begins to build in volume and distortion.
So I drop them off in the  Village and they dart.
Oh God... Max gags and rubs his head.
I get out, grab my bat and  start running. One of the kids,  maybe sixteen, I catch a block  later he's cursing at me, calling  me a Paki bastard. So I whacked him,  right in the head.

Farrouhk! The pain seems to disappear. Max looks at his hand that w rubbing his bead. Then he looks at the front door. The doorknob seems to move.  Something begins knocking on Max's door. The knocking get louder and louder then the locks begin to unlock. FARROUHK's words begin to overpower Max.

I'm kicking the bastard in the  ribs banging his ass, knocking his  head against the curb, harder  and harder, I fucking lost  it. A hot dog guy starts  screaming "You're cracking his  skull, you're cracking his  skull." So they pulled me off  of him and calmed me down.  Cops said he had it coming to  him. Then something starts pounding the door. The doorknob qui the locks unbolt. The chains are the only thing keeping o the intruder. The door shakes and the chains are strained MAX is paralyzed with terror.
No! No! And then the door smashes open. Blinding light fills the and we crash into the
A moment of silence, then we
A phone rings incessantly. Max's eyes pop open. He's scru up in a corner of the room, squashed beneath the sink. His nose is bleeding. Max, crawls into the
and picks up the phone. He pinches his nose and tilts his back.
Mr. Cohen. Marcy  Dawson here again I was just  looking over my schedule and  I realized I'll be in your  neighborhood tomorrow around  three. Max heads to the
and checks the locks. He is barely listening to Marcy
(Groggy)
Who is... The locks seem secure.
Marcy Dawson from  Lancet-Percy I'm so anxious  to meet you. It will be worth  itfor both of us I promise.  See you at your house at  three, okay?
My house...how do...
Oh, don't worry,  I got your address from  Columbia. So three it is.  Looking forward to it. Max tries to stop her but, before he can Marcy hangs up. A bewildered Max slowly hangs up.
Damn. Max checks the peephole - all clear. Then, he opens his -

which is filled with random computer parts and boxes. He pulls a thick neuroscience book from a shelf in the ba the closet. He almost knocks over an old dusty brass  microscope on the shelf. Max flips through the book. It contains old plates  illustrating the brain. Max examines some of the diagrams EXT. S0L'S HALLWAY - DAY Max rings the bell on an apartme door. A few moments pass, and then SOL ROBESON opens the door. Sol is a wise-looking man in his early 70's. He walks wit difficulty, leaning out of breath on a wooden cane. His arms are covered with faded Russian prison tattoos an speaks with a thick Eastern European accent, He's happy t Max.
Max! How are you7 Max is happy to see Sol, but he's a bit bashful and  intimidated. MAX Okay.
TIGHT ON the Japanese game of Go being played. Sol is whi and Max is black. Sol's moves are secure and controlled w Max is hesitant.
Stop thinking, Max, just  feel. Use your intuition.  It's the only way to get into  the flow.  (Beat)
What did you think of Hamlet?
I didn't get to it.
It's been a month.  (Knowingly)
You haven't taken  a single break.
I'm so close, Sol. I'm  so close but I just can't  grab it. Sol changes the subject. He feeds his goldfish and points one of them.
Have you met the new  fish my niece bought me? I  named her Icarus. After you.  My renegade pupil. You fly  too high, you'll get burned. Max looks up at Sol.
The more I see you, the  more I see myself thirty  years ago. My greatest pupil.  Published at 16, Ph.D. at 20.
We'll see.
But life isn't just  mathematics. I spent forty  years looking for patterns in  Pi, I found nothing.
You found things...
I found things, but not a  pattern.
Max sits in the corner of a rickety New York City subway The train is almost completely deserted. Max looks down at his hand. He opens his palm and reveals black Go chip.

Tuesday, September  second, eighteen twelve. If  Sol hadn't gotten sick who  knows where math would be. He  spent years in the numbers of  Pi. Searching for meaning, for  order. Max notices a SKINNY MAN in a business suit staring at hi The man catches Max's eye and looks away, but then he qui looks back, making Max turn away. He looks down at his Wall Street journal and draws a circ with its diameter then he writes "A=pir2" and "C=2pir." N he writes "pi=3.14159..."

Three point one  four...off into infinity  and maybe insanity. Somewhere  in there he wanted sanity.  Sanity like he found in the  circles Pi represented.  Simple, sane circles. If only  the stock market had circles.  Some type of sanity. Some  type of form, of shape. Suddenly, Max hears someone singing. Max looks up. It is Skinny Man and he's singing with passion. It's all very  strange to Max, who nervously looks away. And then the singing stops mid-verse Max looks up and the man is gone. Vanished. Max looks aroundno one in Sight.

Max heads up the stairs to his apartment. Just then, a to SLINKY appears from nowhere marching down the stairs. Max stops and waits until the Slinky hits his foot. He pi it up and looks at it. He looks around wondering what's going on. Then Jenna lea out over a railing and starts laughing at Max.

Max sits at the counter frantically looking at the Wall S Journal. He plops three pills into his coffee. He draws circles and other shapes across the page. Max is interrupted by a puff of smoke. At the same time,  someone touches his shoulder and says:
Hey, Max, how you doing?
Oh, okay.
Lenny Meyer.  (Motioning to the cigarette)
I'll put it out.  (Which be does)
So, what do you do?
Um, I work with computers  ...math.
Really? What type of math?
Number theory. Mostly  research.
Number theory? No  way, I work in theory, too.  Not traditional, though... (Points to his yarmulke)
I work with the Torah.  (Awed by the coincidence)
Amazing.
(Passing it of as a coincidence)
Yeah...
Yeah. You know Hebrew is  all numbers. It's all math.

Hm. Lenny pulls out a worn' dog-eared Bible from his pocket. are paper slips marking what seems like every other page. he opens it up, Max sees that the pages are marked up by highlighter pens notes and diagrams. Lenny points to the text. EXTREME CLOSE-UP of Hebrew lett
Here, look...the ancient  Jews used Hebrew as their  numerical system. Each  letter is a number. Lenny pulls out a pen and grabs Max's Journal. He writes as he talks.
You see...The Hebrew "A," the  number 1. The Hebrew "B,"  Bet, is two. You can take any  Hebrew text and turn them into  a long string of numbers. The waitress refills Max's coffee.
The Torah is just  a long string of numbers.  Some say that it's a long  code sent to us from God. Satisfied, Lenny lights up a cigarette and takes a drag.
(Mildly impressed)
Kind of interesting.
(Proud of himself)

Yeah, like take the  Hebrew word for, say, the  Garden of Eden, Kadem. Kuf,  Dalei Mem...Kuf is a  hundred. Daled, four Mem,  forty. They equal one hundred  and forty-four. Then take the  tree of knowledge...in  the garden, Aat Ha Haim, it  equals two hundred and  thirty-three. Now you can take  that number and...
They're Fibonacci numbers.
Huh?
The Fibonacci sequence.  Italian mathematician, thirteenth century. If you divide  a hundred and forty-four into  two hundred and thirty-three,  it approaches theta.
Theta?
The Greek symbol for the  golden ratio. The golden  spiral. Lenny exhales the smoke. Max quickly graphs the number on Wall Street Journal.
You're right, I never saw  that before. That's the series  you find in nature. Like the  face of a sunflower.
Wherever there's spirals.
You see, there's math everywhere. Lenny's smoke drifts by Max's eyes. SLOW MOTION: MAX'S POV of smoke spirals spinning in front him.
Math everywhere... SLOW MOTION: Max looks down at his coffee cup. He pours c into his coffee. It shoots up and mixes with the black co forming spirals in the mug.
(Serious)
Everywhere... SLOW MOTION: Max looks at the spiral he just drew on the Street Journal. NORMAL SPEED Suddenly, Max stands up.
Oh my God...

Max draws spirals all over his Wall Street Journal. Then takes a thick black marker and draws a giant spiral acros entire page. Max is ecstatic as he pounds code into the computer takes moments to wake up, drops pills, and drinks a Ginseng sod

Simple shapes!  Tuesday, September second.  Twenty-twenty-two. Sol! Sol!  Sol! Shapes in the market.  Why not? And they're spirals!  Spirals! Max traces a big circle on the journal. Then, he cuts it with an X-acto blade. He cuts out the middle of the circl that be has a thin loop like one of those futuristic fris He tears part of the loop and stretches the circle out in front of him into a spiral.

A circle spread out overtime.  It's open-ended. It has a  beginning and it grows and  changes through time. If I  can find where it fits, if I  can spin it and lock it into  a group of numbers, then I  can calculate the future.  Lead into gold. Chaos into  order Madness into sanity. Pain  into bliss. Perfection. Max is about to slap RETURN but he stops himselfhe's nerv Next door, Devi and her boyfriend are making love. He loo the wall with disdain. Then he looks back at the screen,  shrugs and confidently slaps RETURN on his keyboard. Stock prices float across the screen. Max can't believe h eyesthe quotes are absurd.
What the... And then, Euclid crashes. The electricity in Max's room f off. The numbers on Max's screen fade to black. In near ( streetlights) darkness:
Shit!
Max removes a fuse. He replaces it with a penny.

Max tries to reboot Euclid, but nothing happens. He tries second time, but nothing happens. Devi and Farrouhk are still at it. Max puts on a pair of latex gloves. He dons a surgical ma He climbs up to a loft above his monitors. A glass case, cool air by a vent tube, encases some computer parts. He  carefully removes the front glass cover. Then he gets it off he's stunned. Not only have the chips melted down, but a strange flaky substance covers the boa

What the... Max grabs his face, frustrated. Deri and Farroakk are giggling, having a great time. Max  stares at the wall. Then he angrily throws Euclid's mainframe onto the ground lands with a SMASH! Under the mainframe is a small city of ANTS. They scrambl cover. Max furiously attacks them, stomping them out with bands. Then he jumps on the smashed mainframe. He slides to the ground and covers his face.
TIGHT ON a tree branch shaking manically in the wind. Max sits on a park bench watching the branch shake. It  terrifies him. He pulls out the printout of his picks and examines them.

Wednesday, September third,  seven-fifteen. Results: AAR  at fourteen and a halflow,  very low. ABR at six and a  halfjeez. Six and a half, ABR  hasn't been beneath twenty in  ten years. Conclusion:  Simple. There is no pattern.  No pattern. Chaos, chaos, all  chaos. He crumples up his picks and tosses them into a public tr can.
Sol and Max play Go. Sol is peaceful while Max is distant Max plays a piece absently. Sol counters with a deafening atari. Max whispers:
Euclid crashed. I lost  all my data, my hardware.
Your mainframe?
Burnt...
What happened?
I don't know, first I got  these horrible picks. Then  Euclid spits out some  numbers. Never saw anything  like it and then it fries.  The whole machine just  crashed.
You have a printout?
Of?
The picks, the number?
I threw it out.
What was the number it  spit out?
I don't know, just a long  string of digits.
How many?
I don't know.
(Intense)
What was it, a  hundred and fifty, a  thousand, two hundred  sixteen!? How many?
I don't know. Probably  around two hundred.  (Wondering)
Why?
(Beat)...
I dealt with  some bugs back in my Pi days.  I was wondering if it was  similar to one I ran into. Sol begins to feed his fish. He points to one.
Have you met Archimedes.  The one with the black spot.  You see?
Yeah.

Remember Archimedes of  Syracuse? The King asks  Archimedes to determine if a  present he's received was  actually solid gold. Unsolved  problem at the time. It  tortures the great Greek  mathematician for weeks.  Insomnia haunts him and he  twists and turns on his bed  for nights on end. Finally,  his equally exhausted wife,  she's forced to share a bed  with this genius, convinces  him to take a bath, to relax.  While stepping into the tub  he observes the bathwater  rise as he enters. Displacement.  A way to determine volume.  And thus, a way to  determine density, weight  over volume. And thus,  Archimedes solves the  problem. He screams  "Eureka!"Greek for "I found  it!"and is so overwhelmed he  runs dripping naked through  the streets to the King's  castle to report his  discovery. Now, what's the  moral of the story.
That a breakthrough will  come...

Wrong. The point of the  story is the wife. Listen to  your wife, she will give you  perspective. Meaning, you  need a break, Max, you have  to take a bath, otherwise  you'll get nowhere. There will  be no order, only chaos.  Go home and take a bath.

Max waits for his train on an empty platform. Just then, he hears a DRIPPING sound. Max looks up and no something across the tracks on the other platform. He can quite make it out because his vision is blocked by column He gets up and spots a Young Hasidic Man standing at him. Blood drips from the Man's hand. Max doesn't know what to of it

Max reads an ad that says In big block letters 'MOSHIAC I COMING!' He checks out a few of the other passengers. The notices a man reading a newspaper across from him. The headline reads: 'MARKET TAKES NOSE-DIVE. Max jumps up approaches the man.
Hey, excuse me, can I see  that? The man hands Max the paper. Max scans the article. Then quickly turns to the listings. His finger barrels down a  column. It stops at ABR.
Six and a half. Max looks up the column for AAR. MAX
Fourteen and a half. Oh,  my... Max stumbles toward the doors. He looks out the window: i the darkness of the tunnel.
(Out of breath)
My God. My God.  (Gets pumped to himself)
Yes! Yes!
Hey, paper, please! Max hands the paper back and looks at the man for the fir time. It is the Skinny Man he saw earlier. Max gets suspicious and moves into the next car.

Max exits. He notices that the Skinny Man gets off - one down - as well. He hustles toward the exit. As he's about to turn a corne looks back. The man seems to be following him. He dodges around a corner and heads up a staircase.
He seems to have lost him, when he notices a business-wom with a pretty face heading right toward him. It is MARCY  DAWSON.
Mr. Cohen! Perfect timing. Marcy sticks out her hand. Max, not knowing what else to shakes it.
I was just waiting for you.  I thought you stood me up,  so I was going to head home.
Who are you?
Oh...Marcy Dawson. From  Lancet Percy. We were  supposed to meet at three.
I'm sorry, I don't... Marcy hasn't let go of Max's hand. She guides him toward a large black street limo that's ju pulled up.
I can't tell you what a  pleasure it is to finally  meet you. I've studied  your papers for years.
I have something  you won't be able to say no  to. Why don't we take a spin  in the limo?
No, no, no, really, I  can't.

We're excited by your work.  We can't wait to discuss... Max attempts to pull away but Marcy is firm on leading hi the car. Meanwhile, the Shinny man is heading right at th The CHAUFFEUR reaches out to him. Max yanks his arm free runs away. He whips around a corner.
Max barrels into the grocery store and buys a Journal. He heads to the back of the store and lays the paper across juice section. He checks the listing.
On the nose. On the damn nose. Max turns the page on the Journal and sees the Lancet-Per ad. Then he notices one of the bodega owners staring at h
Max scouts his front door. The coast is clear.

Max examines the smashed Euclid mainframe. He uncovers so the strange filo-like substance. He carefully touches it. he grabs a small pinch of it. He examines it near a light bulb. He can't guess what it He sniffs it. He carefully tastes it with the very tip of tongue. He still doesn't have a clue. Max opens his closet. He pulls out his dusty brass micros He dusts it off. Next, he pulls out a slide Kit. Max places the instrument on the windowsill. He grabs an glass slide and puts some of the flaky stuff on it. He sl it under the microscope. He looks into the lens, but does see anything. He gets up quickly and heads for the
where he looks at Devi's door, nervously. He gathers his  courage and knocks on her door. Through the door hears.
Farrouhk?
Um, no, it's Max from next door. Devi opens the door wearing a sexy nightshirt.
Max, is everything all  right?
Do you have any iodine?
(concerned, she reaches for Max's hands)
Iodine...did you cut  yourself?
(Pulling his hands away)
No. I just need it to stain a  slide.
Ah, science, the pursuit  of knowledge. One second. She heads to her bathroom. Max waits impatiently.
Here we are. What are you  examining (At the door)
a potato!? She hands Max a bottle of iodine.
Just something with my  computer.
Max uses his pinky to drip a drop of iodine on the slide. Through the wall he hears Farrouhk arriving home.
The neighbor's up  to his old science...
What neighbor?
Next door. Max listens to the conversation for a few moments.
Why are you talking to that dork!
Shh! I just helped ...
Pounds on wall. Hey, dork, leave my girlfriend alone!

Farrouhk! Max shakes his bead. Then he finishes preparing the slide slips the glass under the turret. Max catches the low-hanging sun in the microscope's mirro reflects it through the sample and up the turret into his eye. MAX'S POV DOWN THE TURRET of some strange Substance. Max pulls out the slide and looks at it.
I don't give a shit.
(Laughing)
Shh! C'mon, Farrouhk.
I'll kill the dork.  (Exploding again)

You hear me! I'll kill you.  I'll fucking kill you! Then an idea comes to him. He takes out his brain book. H looks through it until he finds a picture of neurons. He  compares the image to the view through the turret. They l different but there are similarities.
Shh! Baby! Come here, baby! Max rushes out.

Max sifts through the trash can where he threw his picks yesterday. Frustrated, he dumps the trash onto the sidewa and starts looking through it Mrs. Ovadia watches him. Max sees her and is embarrassed for a moment.
I just threw out something.  I didn't realize I needed it.
Humph.
Just a printout. I, uh,  lost my data... Max looks back at the trash And forgets about Mrs. Ovadia Soon, Max gets up and kicks the trashcan. He heads home.

head_text.subj: IN FRONT OF MAX'S APARTMENT BUILDING

text: Max watches Marcy get out of the limo and call to Mrs. Ov Max backs away when he smacks into someone. It's Lenny Meyer - the young Jewish man. Max jumps back in fear.
Max! How you doing? Lenny  Meyer.
Oh, hey...  Max tries to quickly pass him.
Hey, where you going? You  got a few moments to do Tefillin? Max turns around and notices Marcy talking to Mrs. Ovadia Mrs. Ovadia points up the street toward him.
I gotta car, we can cruise  over to my...
You gotta car?
Yeah, right there. That's  Ephraim, my friend. We swing around with Max and see a station wagon. EPHRAIM sits in the passenger Seat. He's a big-boned, bea Orthodox Jew.
All tight, lets go.
Great... They head for the station wagon.
